Vaccine skeptics are attacking Travis Kelce for participating in a Pfizer advertisement recycling conspiracy theories about Covid19 shots as the NFL star is getting attention for his rumored romance with pop icon Taylor Swift PERIOD

As Swifts fans flooded social media with reactions to her appearance at last Sundays Kansas City Chiefs win over the Chicago Bears some of the internets most notorious disinformers exploited the buzz falsely claiming in posts naming the tight end that vaccines cause widespread heart problems or kill people PERIOD Some barbs hit Swift as well PERIOD

 Charlie Kirk founder of conservative organization Turning Point USA wrote in one of several posts AFP saw echoing a conspiracy theory about the jabs triggering cardiac arrests in athletes PERIOD

Another post from a top promoter of the QAnon conspiracy theory on X formerly Twitter went a step further 

The attempts to hijack the narrative surrounding the celebrity duo underscore how promoters of vaccine misinformation readily take advantage of the days headlines PERIOD

Similar allegations casting vaccines as deadly dominated X and other sites after Buffalo Bills safety Damar Hamlin collapsed in a February incident resulting from a blow to his chest PERIOD

 said Yotam Ophir an expert on health misinformation at the University of Buffalo PERIOD 

 Ophir told AFP PERIOD 

Kelce has long advocated for Covid19 vaccination which have proven safe appearing in a  promotion for the shots with US pharmacy chain Walgreens PERIOD

His paid partnership with Pfizer shows him flashing a pair of bandages on his shoulder while encouraging viewers to get the latest Covid19 booster and a flu shot at the same time PERIOD

The twotime Super Bowl champion disabled comments under his September Instagram post sharing the ad PERIOD But angry users lit up other posts on his page with debunked claims about vaccine safety and personal attacks saying he  for

The rare risk of myocarditis or inflammation of the heart in younger people has seen some countries narrow their booster campaigns but the United States recommends everyone six months and older receive the updated shot PERIOD
